@jkbradley Sounds good. 2x speedups are non-trivial. :-) Looking forward to large-scale test results. Also, thanks for verifying with scikit-learn.

@jkbradley There are couple `math.pow(2, ..)` calls in the implementation. We can use `<<` instead, which is faster than `math.pow`. As mentioned in the comments, if we use 1-indexing for nodes, the index calculation will be much simpler. But I'm not sure about whether this is an easy change.

Sorry for the delay on this. It would be great if the PR also added a unit test to reproduce the bug. I can add that if you don't have time.

Jenkins, retest this please.

I have removed the logic of logging queue length as a warning. This significantly simplifies the PR and fulfills its original purpose as a bug fix. We can add back some notion of warning later on if there is interest.
Passes scala style checks on my laptop now.  Hopefully good to go.  Note: The DTMetadata class becomes more useful in the next planned PR, where it stores the variable number of bins per feature.

[QA tests have finished](https://amplab.cs.berkeley.edu/jenkins/job/SparkPullRequestBuilder/18645/consoleFull) for   PR 1952 at commit [`c818fb2`](https://github.com/apache/spark/commit/c818fb2c470c99178db9ce823d1a039392875f17).
- This patch **passes** unit tests.
- This patch merges cleanly.
- This patch adds the following public classes _(experimental)_:
  - `trait TaskCompletionListener extends EventListener`
  - `class AvroWrapperToJavaConverter extends Converter[Any, Any]`

This isn't quite the right approach, since the call to reduceByKey will result in two rounds of communication and hash aggregations (in reduceByKey and copartitionWithVertices) when only one is necessary. It would be better to add a ShippableVertexPartition constructor that takes a mergeFunc, then just pass the mergeFunc from here into that constructor.

Also, the capitalization in `VD1` and `VD2` suggests that they are type parameters when they are actually function parameters -- they should probably just be `a` and `b`.

I can make these changes this weekend if you like.

And @pwendell, I don't think this is risky. It's a minor change and at least it don't do worse. 
The current implementation doesn't pick the more proper ip on my laptop(mac os x) or a Debian. 
Of course, if you don't want to put this into 1.1, I totally get it. But I hope this can be made into master and later release.

@sryza There are similar things in Scala, but we can not compare the Python object in Scala, so it can not use the groupByKey() in Scala directly. All the aggregation should be implemented in Python also.

@andrewor14,  I hope PySpark could catch up with Scala.
test this please

By risky I mean this - many existing users of Spark might depend on the current behavior, so if we suddenly chose a different interface it will break existing behavior and it could be non-obvious to users why this is happening.
Great - I like this version better!
/cc @mateiz for review (this is the issue I mentioned in #1799).

ok to test

Actually, I retract my earlier LGTM; this needs a bit of user-facing configuration documentation and I think there's a corner-case bug in how we handle late-arriving ACKs.  I'd like for this to make it into the next 1.1.0 preview release, so I may fix these issues myself in a new PR.
Jenkins, retest this please.
